computer|I love my laptops (a beautiful Asus for personal use and a reliable Lenovo for work), and I've been a heavy iPad user since standing in line for the first generation model several years ago. Between laptop and iPad, I wasn't sure there was much space in the middle for a Chromebook. But, when I started reading the rave reviews of the next gen Samsung Chromebook, and when the price fell under two hundred and fifty bucks, I decided to give it a try.And I love it! A huge percentage of my laptop/tablet use is for web browsing and emailing. The Chromebook is purpose-built for both. The Chrome browser works just like it does on my laptop, and being able to have multiple browser windows open is a very nice advantage over my iPad. As you'd expect, the Chromebook works beautifully with gmail, Google Voice, and Google Docs. I wish it ran Skype, but since I've been using Skype and Google video chat and Hangouts pretty interchangeably over the past year, so I don't really miss having Skpe on the Chromebook.For emails longer than a short paragraph, the Chromebook is hugely more convenient than my iPad. I've always loved the convenience of the iPad, but responding to emails that required more than a sentence or two was a pain. In the week I've had the Chromebook, I'd bet my iPad use has dropped by 75%, mostly because I now use the Chromebook as my default email device.I didn't expect to do much if any document creation on the Chromebook, but Google docs works so well that I've found myself using it for short documents (the equivalent of Word docs) and spreadsheets when it's not worth booting up my laptop. I hadn't used Google Docs before, and was very pleasantly surprised by how easy they are to use.Printing: I have two HP printers at home. One is a bit over two years old, and the other is about a year old. Both are new enough to be ePrint compatible. Configuring the Chromebook to print to these printers took only a minute or two -- less time and work than configuring printers on a laptop. Printing to either printer from the Chromebook is just like printing from a laptop -- same dialogues and everything. Slick and simple.Although the Samsung Chromebook will work for anybody, it really comes into its own if you're already embedded in the Google ecosystem. Gmail, Google docs, Google Voice, Google video chat, etc. are ridiculously easy to use on this Chromebook, as you'd expect.In terms of specs, the Chromebook is noticeably lighter than my "thin and light" laptop. The screen is a bit smaller than I'd like -- comparable to the screen on my Lenovo X200 series business laptop, whereas I prefer a minimum 13" screen. But it's a reasonable tradeoff to get a small size, light weight, and great battery life.The battery life has been a real surprise. I used the Chromebook Thursday night, all day Friday, and Saturday morning on a single battery charge before it shut down. The shut down was a bit startling (no warning), but because the Chromebook stores settings, and because the docs I was working on are all in the cloud, everything came back exactly as it was once I plugged in and restarted.The Chromebook starts up very quickly, even when doing a complete reboot. I typically leave it running, and it goes to sleep after a while or when I close the lid. When I open the lid or swipe the touchpad, it comes back to life in about two seconds. This is close enough to instant that I never feel like I'm waiting for the computer to start up. The experience is much closer to using an iPad than a laptop in this regard.And the price is a bargain. A tablet with a keyboard would cost significantly more. (Speaking of price, the cost of this product on Amazon goes up and down dramatically because the device is still in very short supply as of Feb 2013 and stocks out regularly. If you see a price over two fifty, and you're not in a big hurry, wait a week or two and it's likely to fall back to that level.)Bottom line: I couldn't really see why I'd want a Chromebook in addition to my laptop and tablet, but this device actually fits very nicely into a gap between those products. My laptop is bigger, bulkier, and power hungry; and my iPad is great, but is limited without an external keyboard (at which point it's clunkier than the Chromebook) and too expensive to upgrade regularly. The Chromebook has the efficiency, portability, and battery life of an iPad, but with a very nice keyboard at a fraction of the cost.By the way ... a few years ago, I bought a "netbook" for many of the same reasons that attracted me to the Chromebook. But the netbook turned out to be slow (it was Windows based) with a bad keyboard and terrible battery life. The Samsung isn't like the old netbooks, which were basically ultra-cheap laptops. Instead, it's a very sleek machine optimized for web browsing, emailing, and Google apps (Google docs, Google video, Google voice, etc.). In a world that's going to the cloud, I have a feeling that laptops are quickly going to become horse-drawn wagons.

computer|Warning: Holistic, long review incoming.UPDATE: This is a review that describes much of the *potential* usage of this device. Getting the *most* from this "thin-client" requires a certain level of knowledge about Linux, or a certain tenacity for learning. However, because the web is becoming so powerful, you may not need to know anything more than your Google password to get your money's worth from this device. If, however, you want to "kick it up a notch", or just learn a little about what the web really is and where it's headed, read on!-----------------Short vocabulary primer:"native software" : Traditional software (like Microsoft Office) that runs on a specific platform (like MS Windows or Mac OS) and provides high-level functionality to users, usually available offline."webapp" : Web Application. A website using modern programming technologies to provide high-quality software to the end-user, usually intended to replace a native software equivalent. Examples include Gmail, Google Docs (to replace MS Office), Google Calendar (to replace MS Outlook), Angry Birds, and countless others in the Chrome Web Store."X11" : A Linux program responsible for the display and basic management of windows on your screen in just about any Linux computer, including this Chromebook. Also ships by default with Mac OS X!"ssh" : "Secure SHell". A fast, secure way of accessing the command-line of another computer (a "server") through the computer you're sitting at (a "client"). Provides lots of powerful tools for client-server communication and data transfer."X11-forwarding" : A way of telling X11 to send data through SSH. This allows you to run windowed (not just terminal) applications on a remote computer while displaying the resulting windows, buttons, text, etc. on the computer you're sitting in front of - i.e. this Chromebook."chroot" : "CHange ROOT". This is an advanced feature. A way of hot-swapping Unix-based operating systems WITHOUT rebooting your computer. This provides a way to run a traditional operating system and native software alongside Chrome OS, greatly enhancing its offline capabilities. Easy to set up thanks to project "crouton" by dnschneid, available on GitHub (can't link it in a review, sorry!), which provides a simple hotkey for changing operating systems on-the-fly!-----------------TL;DR: Contrary to what other reviewers would lead you to believe, Chrome OS offers thin-client capabilities beyond that of simple web browsing due to the advanced state of modern web and networking technologies. Use this device as a gateway to your other machines using remote protocols like SSH and FTP, and you'll get much more use out of it -- and a little Linux knowledge will go a long way!Many other reviewers have talked about the hardware, the software, the ups-and-downs of the Samsung $250 Chromebook. I'm not going to talk about that -- much. Instead, this review will be half discussion, half "how-to". As far as the hardware goes: suffice to say the device has a decent screen, good touchpad, GREAT keyboard, and is silent, efficient, and affordable. This design philosophy of efficiency and minimalism extends into the software of this machine. With modern computers and even portable devices getting ever-larger, more powerful, and more power-hungry, this choice of design can be a little off-putting. Here's why the Chromebook, and the underlying Chrome OS, has a vital place among your other devices because of this unusual design choice.(NB: The jaw-dropping Chromebook Pixel was released recently, which flies in the face of the minimalist design of the software shared by these two devices. In my opinion, it's a giant step in the wrong direction, and this $250 device is superior in design in almost every way. Here's why.)I couldn't find any reviews that discussed what this device is really capable of, so I thought I'd post my own thoughts. People tend to emphasize how little a Chromebook can do - what you lose when you make the switch. That's not at all what I see when I look at a Chromebook. But first, some background: I consider myself a "power user", and I'm writing to people who want to get the most from this device like I do. I'm experienced with Linux, I subscribe to basically every Google service, and I love getting a little command-line action (to taste). I've installed and used Arch Linux several times on various computers, and I've developed a taste for the brand of minimalism presented by lightweight Linux like Arch and Chrome OS. That said, I was initially underwhelmed when I got my Chromebook; it really seems like "just a browser" at first glance, just as most other reviewers would have you believe. Believe me, it has much more to offer. In truth, there's a whole Linux system under Chrome OS that's capable of much more, and it doesn't take much effort to bring it out.Please note that my usage of this device is by no means typical, but it exposes areas of Chrome OS's potential that are left untapped by the average user. My work as a student involves lots of web searches, document composition using Google Docs, computer program development and compiling using an editor and gcc, data processing and graphing using Google Sheets and GNUPlot, document processing using LaTeX, and VPN access to my university's network. The Chromebook handles even my most advanced use-cases beautifully, thanks in large part to web applications and technologies outside the Chrome OS itself -- and here's how.The ultimate power-user option is to simply dual-boot with a "real" Linux distro - for example, Ubuntu ARM. I've shied away from this option because of hardware compatibility concerns, battery life issues, and space limitations; the same argument can be made against a "chroot" environment, which is another solid power-user option. I do, generally, want to use this device for the web, so sticking with Chrome OS is a logical choice - besides, performance in Chrome OS is second-to-none, as this device truly does boot in the advertised 7 seconds. What's more, I really do enjoy the clean, minimalistic feel of Chrome OS: no desktop icons, no (visible) complex folder structures, no micromanaging files or bookmarks between devices, no bloatware, no fuss. It's great!UPDATE: chroot'ing into a traditional OS works beautifully and is very easy to set up using a project called "crouton" by dnschneid on GitHub. Well worth a look!But within the first ten minutes of using the device, I found that I wanted it to be more than "just a browser," and that's when something clicked. Instead of thinking about this device as a browser, I now call it a "thin client". It's a gateway to the internet and to your other machines. This is by no means a primary computer for someone like me, but it can be used as an interface to a primary computer. This crucial concept can be implemented in many ways, but my primary use-case has been with SSH, or "secure shell". With a little creative port-forwarding, I set up an SSH server to run on both my home server (running Debian) and my desktop (running Ubuntu), each accessible from the internet on its own port. While opening a port to the internet is generally inadvisable, securing the SSH connection with a password or (preferably) a private key provides a sufficient barrier to the outside world, in my opinion. Forwarding another port allowed me to wake or even boot my desktop over the internet using Wake-on-LAN technology, so I don't have to worry about leaving it on all the time and the amount of electricity being sucked down by its mammoth 750W PSU.With an SSH server running on my desktop and server, it was then a simple matter of pressing CTRL+ALT+T on the Chromebook, typing "shell" at the prompt, and using a simple bash alias to initiate the SSH session. Once I'm connected, I have full access to my desktop's considerable horsepower or my server's vast storage from anywhere in the world using my new Chromebook - a light, power-efficient, sleek, and easy-to-replace interface to my other devices. While most of my work technically happens on my desktop, it no longer has to happen at my desktop. I've found that I can get serious work done on my desktop using my Chromebook from the living room, on campus, or anywhere with WiFi. Remote-accessing my primary computer has afforded me a new degree of freedom with where I work without changing how I work.There are limitations to this approach, namely the difficulty of using graphical applications over the network; X11 forwarding over SSH has issues with the redrawing mechanism of Chrome OS's Aura window manager, resulting in orphaned remote windows that are only visible when they are being redrawn. Despite this, I've found that terminal access to my machines is more than enough for writing programs using vim, compiling using gcc (with my desktop's full horsepower), copying files to/from my server or desktop using scp ("secure copy"), and running/debugging my programs remotely. Familiarity and comfort at the command-line allows me to perform these tasks smoothly over a nearly lag-free SSH connection instead of resorting to slower, more graphically-intense, and ultimately less-elegant options like VNC, RDP, or Chrome Remote Desktop.Of course, the thin-client concept extends to more than just a server-client relationship with your own hardware. Web apps are becoming more advanced as web technologies continue to develop rapidly. For me, a shining example of this evolution is a small website called ShareLaTeX. ShareLaTeX is a free or subscription-based service that allows you to compose in the document-programming language LaTeX using only a modern browser, complete with syntax-highlighting, error-checking, and code completion. You can store all of your document's assets on their servers, access them from anywhere, and compile your document into a PDF or DVI using the server-side compiler. You can even view your source code and the output PDF side-by-side in their well-designed web interface. Additionally, ShareLaTeX provides a "Google Docs"-style collaboration feature that allows you to compose documents with several other users. (But, this isn't a ShareLaTeX review, so let's move on.)Even if you don't use or care about LaTeX, it's important to take stock of what this means for the web as a whole. It comes down to this: processor-heavy tasks like compiling programs are being offloaded to a server, while the (lightweight) interface can be presented on something much less beefy. It's this brand of duality that tech companies like Google, Apple, Microsoft, Sony, and countless smaller companies like ShareLaTeX are pushing as the future of the web. As a prospective Chromebook user, this should put a big smile on your face, and here's why:Web-based software, and the software to which you can interface on your own devices, will just keep getting better and better. The web simply will not go "out of date" for the foreseeable future, meaning that it's nigh-impossible for your Chromebook to go out-of-date, no matter how processor-intensive the software of the future becomes. Bolstering this is the fact that Google regularly releases updates for Chrome OS every six weeks, and to date even the venerable Cr-48 (the very first Chromebook) runs the latest version, meaning our considerably more powerful Samsung Chromebook will be supported on the software side for a very, very long time.In conclusion, the Samsung Chromebook and its unique Chrome OS embodies a paradigm shift in mobile computing that can be difficult to grasp for the average user. I urge you to think of this computer as a "thin client", an interface to the web and to your own devices. Web and network technologies like SSH, FTP, and HTML5 allow you to access resources far surpassing those on-board this device -- whether those resources are your own, or those offered by one of an increasing number of web services. Chrome OS serves as a gateway to those resources and services, therefore its relevance as a platform must be evaluated in terms of the quality of said resources and services. Knowledge, then, becomes critical: knowledge of the command line, desktop software that can run via command line (like GNU Octave and GNUPlot), and web services relevant to your own work will allow you to use the web and your Chromebook in exciting, productive new ways. Thanks for reading, and I hope you've learned something from this review!

computer|I was not impressed by the initial Chromebooks. I simply couldn't justify to myself paying that much for what amounted to a seriously crippled laptop only marginally less expensive than a low-end real thing. Now this Chromebook came and it changed everything because of its significantly lower price and a the clear improvement in quality, features and performance.I've only used mine for a few days now but I can tell already that it's a keeper.THE BIG PLUSES- It's affordable. Big time. You simply can't beat the price for anything decent 'laptop-like'. Yes, you could get a Nexus 7 for about the same price, or a Kindle but...- Screen size. Related to the above. There's a lot more square inches of screen on the Chromebook. Yes, much lower pixel density when compared to current tablets but...- Keyboard. Try to write a few dozen emails or THIS review (I'm writing it now) on a tablet. Not a pleasant undertaking. Sure, keyboards come with most laptops but...- Light as a feather. Well, 2 pounds is not exactly feather-weight but you'd be spending a lot more for a decent laptop.- No fans, no moving parts, not much heat.- Safe. As in "it doesn't matter if your Chromebook gets stolen, shatters into a thousand little pieces or melts" for as long as your data goes to the cloud. All you need is a new one - hopefully it was under warranty when the accident happened - or you can get to your data from a friend's Chromebook or access it through whatever it takes to get to your storage area in the 'cloud'.- Quality stuff. It really is. The Keyboard compares favorably to the the ones you'd normally pair with a tablet and even to MacBook's.- Ports. Not all laptops and tablets come with HDMI ports and even fewer have USB 3.0.- 100GB of free storage on Google's cloud forever. Well... sort of. Whatever you place there for the first 2 years stays there forever but you'll have to pay for additional storage after 2 years.I've been using computers and related gadgets since... I can remember and not many triggered a 'wow' reaction from me but this is one of them. For background, we have probably 3 dozen 'things' on our home Wi-Fi network at this time: a desktop, media servers, a few laptops, more tablets than I can count, smart phones, game consoles (both large and portable), Internet radios, receivers... you name it, all eager to serve our many work and entertainment needs (large family) but I can see how I won't be this Chromebook's only user for more than one reason.- Larger screen than a tablet's makes for a better video watching experience.- Attached keyboard makes in the preferred choice when emailing or text-chatting.- Quick boot time (5 seconds?) makes it always available when needed, unlike laptops, desktops.- Connectivity and 'ports' allow for easy expansion. My favorite is pairing with some decent Bluetooth speakers when watching a movie.THE MAJOR MINUSESOf course, not everything is perfect. Nothing ever is.There are some reasons to be concerned, mainly having to do with the availability of your data and its safety. It really comes down to 'do you trust Google with your data?' and to 'do you trust Google to always be there to provide you access to your data?'. My take on this is: do NOT store anything on anyone's cloud that you wouldn't share with a stranger and you wouldn't care much if you lost it. I always keep my personal and confidential data backed up more than once and on devices that can't be easily accessed by 'everyone'. My experience with Gmail is that Google's cloud is quite reliable for keeping casual information and I have no intention of storing anything other than casual content on Google's cloud in the future unless I find some perfect encryption scheme.The other issue is the availability of 'apps'. Google is in full control of what you can run on your Chromebook. If Google decides that you may not run Netflix tomorrow, Netflix is gone. And it's unlikely that you'll ever see Microsoft Office at Google's store. So, it all comes down to how happy you are with what Google offers you today and how confident you are that you are going to be happy with Google one year from now. But, to me, at this price, this is not big deal.I LOVE ITWhich explains my 5 star rating. I know, love needs not be explained or justified but, since I have a pretty good idea why I love this Chromebook, here it is. The price makes up for most of it, then it's the near-instant availability, the near-worry free availability of the apps expect to use most with it: entertainment, emails, text and video chats and the reasonably well engineered body that's light, comes with a decent display, good keyboard, most essential expansion ports.-->> Brush your teeth, it's the law! &lt;&lt;

computer|tl;dr: Nice with ChromeOS, but I recommend the 3G version if you use it not just at home; /very/ nice with Linux. Both opinions take the price into consideration.Arrived from Amazon Warehouse deals in mint condition.Boot time and general usability for web browsing is amazing, considered the price: you don't get a MacBook Air, but then you also don't have to pay the price of the latter. The keyboard is one of the best I've seen in laptops of this size, although you might miss the F11 and F12 button and the &#34;correct&#34; positioning of the function keys if you plan to not only use Chrome. Also, page up/down keys would have been nice, but you can get around without them. The display is okay; brightness is not too high, but it's matte, not glossy, so for serious applications I actually like it more than some of the displays usually ranked better. One real drawback is that the angle in which you can open the display is quite restricted; a little more would have been better. The touchpad is also nice, but be aware that it doesn't support real multitouch (like pinch-zooming and rotation). Overall, the build quality is amazingly good, it is rather light and feels pretty robust for a device that inexpensive.Battery life seems to match the advertisements; 6h are realistic. For international users (I know, I know, you're not supposed to export this; just in case you still are a naughty girl): the AC adapter comes with a Mickey Mouse plug (IEC C5/C6), so you can just buy an according power cable and use wherever you go.After a few hours, I did what I planned to do in the first place: get Linux on it. Installing Ubuntu (using crouton) worked like a charm within minutes, and makes this machine useful also on the road without internet connection. Switching between the two operating systems (in this setup, they run side-by-side, both using the ChromeOS kernel) is instantaneous. Camera, microphone and speakers work in Linux. (But there are stories that you can melt your speaker with some settings, so be careful or wait until these issues are reported as resolved; use your google-fu and don't trust anybody.) Playing movies worked smoothly with mplayer (faster than on ChromeOS, actually). This might be different if you don't use the ChromeOS kernel, though, because AFAIK there is no good open source support for the rendering hardware yet.You can get most important applications for a Linux system like this, but be prepared to put in more configuration effort than for a standard desktop system. In part because you have to configure the system nicely for the screen size and to use the function keys not too often (this gets annoying because you won't hit the correct ones blindly), but also because you lack the Windows or Apple key between Ctrl and Alt, which typically is important for the window managers. (You can, however, reconfigure the &#34;search&#34; key at Caps location to resemble a fn key, to get page up/down and home/end as second-level options of the arrow keys.) Besides, the entire setup is non-standard - Chromebooks don't boot as usual PCs, due to an additional indirection layer before the BIOS; the use-the-ChromeOS-kernel configuration is not what distributions usually intend to work on; and the SSD drive (which really is a 16GB eMMC) is not what you typically find these days on a random machine.I'm not sure how a more demanding desktop environment will perform; crouton's &#34;default&#34; I'm currently using is XFCE, which is pretty fast, but I usually use awesome, which is even less resource intensive. Besides, I don't need graphics that much; thus, 2D and 3D performance is no dealbreaker for me. But, as I said, movies work fine.One important thing to note: Skype is currently not available on ARM chips other than smartphones. This not only means ChromeOS, but also Linux. I repeat: no Skype currently, and it looks like Microsoft doesn't (yet) have mid-term plans to change this. I've tried with qemu, but haven't been successful so far. But then again, there is a growing number of people in the Linux community playing around with inexpensive ARM-based hardware like this Chromebook and also the RaspberryPi, so I expect that the ARM ecosystem will develop very fast in the next few months. Invest and wait, or invest and help!If you don't plan to upgrade to a &#34;full-grown&#34; operating system but use it anywhere else than your sofa, consider buying the 3G version instead. ChromeOS itself is no fun without internet connection.

computer|First thing this thing is purpose built to do 1 thing, get you on the Internet. Expecting it to do anything else and your expecting to much. Yes it may play SOME video file types and audio but it is hardly built for that and a normal machine with VLC or some other video player will do the job vastly better. Your limited to using online services to do anything, but have offline Google Docs/Scratchpad and a couple other things. There is the 2 years worth of 100gb online storage, which is good for backing up files online so you can quickly access them on the go since your 16gb HD will get filled quickly if you try to use it. I personally just use the 100gb free storage for backing up files off site.If your buying this with the expectation of using the 100gb of online storage as if it was a hard drive, don't. It's best used as a backup of your data and to quickly upload your newly made files in Google Docs and such so you can access it anywhere with an Internet connection. As trying to rely on an Internet connection to get the data isn't a good way to go about it, and sometimes it has taken a few minutes for things to show up in the Google Drive folder on the laptop itself. Which trust me put me into a bit of a panic after I wrote a 4 page essay and it wasn't appearing when I needed to submit it in a few hours. After 10min or so it finally appeared. This is one of the small bugs or shortcomings I found with the OS, there were 1-2 other bugs I found after I thoroughly put it through it paces in the last few weeks. May sound like a lot, but honestly I find more on my primary Win 7 desktop machine in the same time frame, the difference is that I have other options in terms of programs on the Windows machine so I can ignore it. Where as with this I have to work with it.What everyone says is true the boot time is incredibly fast. Never felt the need to time it myself. It will get your online so you can check emails/facebook/etc. With me I personally bought it for school, which means I will end up using Google docs for notes and writing assignment (than putting it into a real word processor before submitting, so I can use spelling/grammar check). As well and researching assignments all of which this thing will do quite well.What this laptop is though is the exact definition of K.I.S.S (Keep It Short and Simple). It is a stripped down OS with cheap quality hardware which was selected to give the best user experience, not benchmark experience. The arm A15 1.7ghz dual core is more than capable of handling all tasks this was designed for (Internet) and the SSD provides a quick boot experience, quality keyboard/touchpad and overall build quality. The only grip here is with the screen with bad viewing angels, and how the light sensor keeps adjusting the screen too much based on the light condition.The OS itself is one of the things I like the most. It is highly sandboxed with how the OS was designed, with updates pushed silently in the background. And all the user data is encrypted with 128bit encryption, and quite a bit of other encryption found in various other places in the OS using the TPM. Something I won't go into as it's a good read if you look into it, and some of it goes over my head so I'd rather not spread false information. For me the encryption part is quite important as it is a laptop and will be used on the go and having it lost/stolen will just mean I lose the device itself and not half to worry about personal information being compromised. Assuming it is powered down, or signed off not just a locked screen (and you used a good strong password). The OS also has a "Self Healing" which I hear some people refer to it as, when the computer turns on it checks against a known good version of itself to check for tampering and if there is any tampering it will use that instead of the tampered version.The biggest strength this laptop has is also it's weakness. It is built with simplicity in mind. It carries the mentality of "If it works it works, if it doesn't it doesn't" there are pretty much no workarounds to that (K.I.S.S as I referred to it earlier). Where as with a Window or "real" Linux based machine there is almost always a workaround you can do to get the job done. Where as with this if something doesn't work your out of luck, your not given the ability to install any actual programs or any real control in the computer settings. The amount of control in the computer settings is what you find in the Chrome Browser and a few other small settings which I wouldn't mind someone computer illiterate play with (AKA no real ability to change anything). But you do have the option to change the "search key" back to "caps lock" if you choose to do so. Though personally I found more use for the search key as it brings up the minimized taskbar and will search the Internet and various other things for you.In short this laptop is made to be used on the Internet, nothing more nothing less. If you want a laptop to do basic web browsing on the cheap this is for you. If you want something to write up paper and do web browsing, you can do that to. But I highly recommend loading up what you write into a real word processor so you can take advantage of spelling/grammar check and all the other features Google Docs doesn't provide or provide a good enough version of as I find it quite basic. In terms of buying this for school, I find it would be quite good for that so far from playing with it for the last several weeks though I haven't had a chance to try it out in class myself yet. As I already put several notes into Google docs so far, and have had great battery life with this. You can easily make it through any class without charging.And to answer your question you may be asking yourself. Yes it's a great little laptop and worth buying IF you can manage to work within it's limitations. If you want to know if you can, install chrome on your computer and try to use nothing but that and Google docs, Google drive, and other Google web based programs for a day or two. The rest of the OS is quite simple to learn, it took me less than 10min to figure out almost everything I could do with it due to having experience with Chrome Browser. It also has chrome remote access so you can remote access your Windows based machine to do quick amount of real work while on the go, but it isn't something I rely on if you can.

computer|We were really excited about this Chromebook. It's truly a beautiful machine. Very light. Very well designed generally and looks and feels much like a clone of a MacBook Air. Excellent keyboard. The Chrome operating system is what it is: a good idea for some people and maybe not really that terrific for others.Apparently, these little machines are flying off the shelves because we had to wait for ours for a while, even with a Prime purchase.Anyway, we were disappointed. We wanted so badly for it to work, it was quite the downer that it seems not quite ready for primetime. Or, to put it somewhat differently, it has a problem which a $250 consumer item shouldn't have: connectivity is very problematic.The short version of this is that a machine that requires that it be online for any significant functioning had better not have any issues about getting online. Ours did, and bad issues at that. In retrospect, we realize we disregarded warnings about connectivity, which appear quite frequently in reviews of this machine online. Of course, one never knows with such things what the level of expertise of the reviewer might be and all the time you see reviews essentially announcing that the reviewer is a complete novice and maybe should be asking his teenage son how to do things instead of complaining about the item being reviewed.Our home is served by an recent Airport Extreme wireless router. There are many items connected and none have ever had a problem. Indeed, my students will frequently visit our house with their many varied laptops and none of them has ever had a problem connecting to the system. But this Chromebook refused completely. By the way, it had no trouble at all with connecting to our neighbors unprotected network through walls and down the street so if it's a hardware issue it certainly isn't a simple one of an obviously defective part.My wife works in IT tech support so she toyed with the idea of taking our network apart to find what sort of gremlin might be locking out this one machine out of all the dozens that have connected flawlessly. Of course it was my spousal responsibility to be sure that she would be able to do that successfully, but that left me wondering about whether I could just take her along wherever I took the machine, to fix up similar mysterious refusals to connect.I don't want to seem cranky about this, since we both really liked the machine and even though we packed it up and sent it back to Amazon, our plan is to lurk, giving Samsung and Chrome a bit more time to bring their product up to speed. Then we'll try again. But, for right now our verdict is that a machine aimed at the low end consumer market shouldn't have even the slightest issue of the sort we encountered.Oh, we aren't claiming that our experience is typical. We didn't push deeply into our configuration. We certainly didn't remap our entire network or pull items off one by one etc etc. The point, again, is that no one should have to do that for an always online consumer laptop.

The CS representative was friendly and helpful, and easy to understand as English was her primary language, unlike most other CS online experiences I'm encountering lately for other companies. Amazon will overnight ship a replacement Chromebook at no cost to me, and will email me a return label also at no cost to ship the package back. And, they are not waiting for the defective item to arrive before sending the new one. What's not to love about Amazon? Seriously...Also noticed that in the advanced Chromebook settings, there is a way to "wipe" the machine back to factory settings. I really appreciate how basically user friendly this machine seems to be. Not quite the same as an apple device, they practically reach thru the display and guide your hand to what you want to do, but easy...one of the reasons I did not want a small windows laptop or netbook was how unintuitive it is to do what you need to do even for simple setting changes or adjustments. I find myself totally frustrated when I go back to using my DELL laptop after my Ipad because of the Windows platform with a million windows to click through. I'm glad Google has come up with what I hope continues to be a very respectable alternate for basic functions (please, I'm not a tekkie so don't jump on this, want a small basic machine that won't get bogged down with the issues a Windows machine experiences) I'm hoping I can also use Chromebook away from my home wifi, using my iphone as a hotspot so I can take advantage of using the internet on a larger display. Originally I had an android smart phone, a samsung galaxy Fascinate with a nice large display. I switched to an iphone 4 and was not thrilled with the small screen, even though I like most everything else. computer|I ordered the Chrome Book because I wanted a portable device for note-taking and document access. (While I originally considered an ultra-book, I decided to keep separate applications with sensitive data like Quicken from other cloud-based documents. Based on that concern, I elected to maintain a home-based laptop and to buy the Chrome Book for on the go.) At $249, you cannot beat the price for the Chrome Book.The Chrome Book is extremely light-weight (~2 pounds) and meets my standards for portability. The keyboard is very comfortable and easier to use than a touch screen with either a stylus or an add-on keyboard. (I admit that I find it challenging to type on a touch screen and that I don't like fingerprints.) The device looks stylish.From a set-up perspective, it is important to ensure that your wi-fi encryption is set to WPA2. (Our router was originally set to use the older standard of WEP.) When I first turned on the Chrome Book, the device was extremely slow - taking many minutes to access a web page. As soon as I changed the encryption standard, the Chrome Book speed became good and responsive. If you are currently using WPA2, set-up is as easy as turning on the device and signing into Gmail.If you don't have wi-fi access, the Chrome Book does allow you off-line access to both Gmail and Google Drive.To gain full utility from this device, you need to buy-in to using Gmail and Google Drive. (You can access MS Office docs on a flash drive.) I have been impressed by the collaboration capabilities with Documents on Drive. (If you are committed to using Outlook or another reader to access your mail locally, the Chrome Book will NOT work for you.)Google makes available 100GB of storage on Drive for 2 years if you buy a Chrome Book. In order to take advantage of this storage, you need to search for Chrome Book "goodies" online.A disappointment with the Chrome Book is that you cannot access the New York Times application with off-line availability. (You can sign in and read the NY Times with the Skimmer application. You need wi-fi connectivity to use the Skimmer.) While I pay for an online Times subscription, the Chrome tablet application will not work. Every time you try to access an article, it prompts you to log-in but it then routes you back to the home page instead of opening the article. (If you look at the reviews on the Chrome Store web site, many users report the same problem.)While the Kindle Cloud application will allow you to access your newest book via the Chrome Book, it will not allow you to access your subscriptions.)I think this is a good device if you want a portable gadget for office functionality. If you are traveling and want access to entertainment, I don't think this is the optimal device. (Without a memory stick add-on, you can't download media for access without wi-fi.)

computer|Update - decided to keep it and give it another star.First of all, I might say that I'm a little indifferent to the Chromebook - hence the (original) 3 star rating. I have the last return date circled in my calendar, and have the bubble wrap and box all ready to go. Meanwhile I'll try to find out where it fits (if anywhere) in my computer collection, and if I can adapt to the Chromebook world. If I keep it, I'll give it another star.Years ago, when you used a computer to do serious work, you used a terminal connected to a larger computer. An unconnected terminal (even an "intelligent terminal") didn't do much on its own. It was a rather care-free life. If you terminal stopped working, you simply found another one and picked up where you left off. Viruses (at an individual level) were unheard of. I think of the Chromebook is a modern interpretation of the terminal. You get all the advantages (statelessness, no individual viruses, no software to install, no maintenance), but it needs to be connected, and your experience is only as good as what is on the other end.First of all, the hardware is top notch. I could easily give it 5 stars. It's silent, lightweight but solid, and the display is very good. Battery life seems to be better than most laptops, but not quite as good as an iPad. In terms of performance, I'd say it's better than any Windows machine near this price range. My favorite test is scrolling rapidly through a Facebook news feed. It's almost as fast as a high-powered Mac.The software/OS is basically a web browser with a LIMITED set of plug-ins. unlike an iPad, you have Flash available, and there is some magic to allow you to save a few things off-line, access external drives, etc. Apart from that, you probably can't install plugins. The Java site says I don't have Java, but Wikipedia sound clips work (yay).One amazing feature is remote desktop access. I can barely read what I'm typing, but I'm typing this on my chromebook connected to my mac. I think this just made the keep decision.Although you can minimize the web browser, there doesn't seem to be much point. There is an "app store", and the most common price seems to be "free". "Bookmark store" might be a better term (a "bookmark store" is a great improvement over one well-known browsers habit of simply filling your bookmarks with its choice of bookmarks). Some apps (such as Evernote) are simply the same as the web interface available to everyone. Email is limited to web-based email (luckily most email providers and corporate email servers provide (usually awkward web based interface). A few "apps" seem quite pointless - such as a "wikipedia" app which does nothing but display ads in the margin while you read genuine Wikipedia articles with the margins cut off. Google maps is the same as the awkward web version (two-fingered scroll = zoom, scrolling means clicking on the little compass circle). Many Google "apps" create several tabs for simple operations. For example, reading a book via Google Play may open 3 tabs (only one of them is the book). This can get a little confusing. Then again, the whole tabbed interface avoids the issues of having multiple programs open, each with its own tabbed interface.Finally - (despite the hype, but true to the fine print) offline behavior is currently VERY limited. I was able to edit a Google Doc (Google Docs are kept off-line) without wifi, and the document synced as soon as I was back within wifi range. Perhaps other sites will gradually acquire Chromebook off-line behavior, but for now don't expect to work offline and pop into your local cafe for a quick cup of coffee and daily sync. The good news is that you can "try out" the Chromebook experience using any type of computer that runs Google Chrome. This might save you a trip to the post office.

computer|All features and benefits are there; also all caveats about limited offline functions. What more I ask of the maker (firmware?) is driver support for Ethernet. Some brands of chromebook *do* support USB adapters for Ethernet (usb 2 allows up to 1 gigabit/second data; usb 3 allows up to 5 gb/s). Alas the 3g model in 4/2013 does not. Also in the "I wish" category, I wish the blue-tooth connectivity (currently for mouse & full-size keyboards sold separately) would extend to direct transfer Chromebook to chromebook (and to other devices one identifies). Lastly, I have learned that the 3g model has a SIM card slot and that one can take this Chromebook to Europe and buy service on a SIM card there, month to month. The steps to "enable Global SIM card" involve manually typing a command at the CTRL+ALT+T prompt. It is too bad that Samsung and/or google don't point this out more prominently as an added feature to travelers who love this device's portability, speed and simplicity.

computer|There's a lot to like about this unit. PROS: It's lightweight. Setup (from opening the box to getting online) is minutes (at most). The screen is beautiful. Once set up (with your Chrome account), there are lots of settings and using the unit is simple. The thing is FAST! From power-up to getting online is maybe 20 seconds, except for one thorny issue I have, for which I have already contacted Samsung. Which brings me to the CONS: You MUST (and there's no way around this) sign into your Chrome account EVERY time you boot this machine. This almost prompted me to send it back. The password must be 8 characters, which is even more annoying. If I'm the only user, why do I need to log in and out? Even if you check &#34;Keep Logged In&#34; on your regular Chrome account, you'll have to login every time here. No saving passwords, either. Stupid. Archaic. This alone almost made me send the thing back. After multiple steps, the help menu and poring over the ADVANCED setup (it's not at all like Windows), I was finally able to set my default web page to Google on startup. The Chrome default page requires more clicks to get there every time. Additionally, to place the HOME button in the browser you have to again find the appropriate (and well hidden) settings menu. Once set up (and I hope it never loses its settings), it was fine. The power plug is EXTREMELY small and tight-fitting. I wonder if one good bump on the rear will break it? Time will tell...In actual use, there's more to like (love): Startup and shutdown is a single-button breeze. Connection to my DSL is fast. You can set up any network and allow automatic connecting (storing your password/WEP key). The keypad is large. A row of dedicated &#34;function&#34; keys above the number keys makes adjustments of volume, brightness and more pretty simple. After charging, the battery shows 6.5 hours of remaining time. This is great for me - if it really lasts that long (time will tell). Opening the lid automatically boots the machine to save even more time. Unlike with Windows, there are no adjustments (that I have found) for screen timeout/dimming, telling the machine what to do when you open/close the lid or hit the power button. It's simple and straightforward - which essentially was what I wanted, though a bit more customizing would be preferable). Inserting an SD card quickly opened a window of its contents. When initially setting up the unit (or going back later), you can use the built-in webcam to snap your picture or load another as a login profile picture. You can set up many Apps within Chrome and download anything you like to the desktop. Font sizes are adjustable and in many ways like within Windows/IE. There is no delete key, only a backspace key. Odd. Menus are somewhat different than within Windows, but as long as things are there, I'll find them, so I have no major complaints about that. All web pages and Apps I tested loaded faster than either of my PCs with XP or Vista (but then anything is faster than those operating systems), but I say this as a comparative: this Samsung unit overall is very fast, opens and scrolls pages quickly, plays YouTube videos very well and though a bit quirky and limited, setting up the browser is simple. Saving web pages (bookmarking) doesn't provide a traditional Favorites List, but maybe I just haven't figured out how to display it? To be fair, I haven't used Chrome until now, and I'm not a huge fan, but it works. I bought this thing for internet only - no Apps. Oh, and the native GMail pops up in a flash. When I called Samsung for support I got to a knowledgeable (English speaking!) guy in minutes, which was refreshing.Overall, I like it and maybe with a some future software updates, I'll learn to love it. I wold recommend it to anyone looking for a FAST machine that will NOT get viruses (according to Samsung, since there's no OS). If you are afraid of computers but want or need internet and email, this machine is a great choice and is priced right (I paid $249.00 on Amazon).

Long story short: buy it for the portability and the price, but don't expect this to be your only computer, unless the only thing you do is browse the web.

computer|For the last several months, my Toshiba Satellite laptop keyboard has been malfunctioning and I had begun searching for a replacement. I had hoped to find the perfect hybrid Windows 8 tablet but was sidetracked when I read page after page of positive Chromebook reviews. I purchased my Samsung Chromebook at the local Best Buy fully expecting to be wowed and to quickly fall in love with it.After two days of working with it, I wouldn't say that I'm in love with it nor could I say that the concept of using a glorified browser and cloud services seems as preposterous as I had once imagined. As many have noted, the good keyboard, respectable build quality and lightweight make a positive first impression. The track pad makes a less favorable impression.I discovered after a great deal of frustration that it does not support two finger tap gestures. The Chromebook help screen claims that tapping with two fingers simulates a right click. I incorrectly assumed that Google docs did not support spelling suggestions. When I tried to right-click on misspelled words, nothing happened and I was almost ready to box it up and return it to Best Buy. After some searching on the Internet, I discovered that the Samsung Chromebook requires you hold down the Alt key while tapping to right-click. I often found myself wanting to reach out and touch the screen because scrolling is so tedious.(See update below for correction to this comment.)When compared with competing Chromebooks, the display leaves much to desire but as others have noted the matte finish compensates enough to save it from a deal killer rating. I have yet to get a handle on how much battery life to expect but it certainly exceeds the 2 -3 hours I get when using my Toshiba.Others have been impressed with the "Instant On" Chrome OS but as a Windows 8 user, I am less impressed. I've grown accustomed to my Windows 8 computers being available for use within seconds of switching them on. However, I am impressed by the quality of audio produced using the built in speakers. As with the display, the sound is a bit muddy but better than what I am accustomed to when using portable devices.A major disappointment is the lack of support for Bluetooth audio devices. I often use my LG Bluetooth headset to listen to streamed podcasts and music. Strangely, the LG device is displayed after it's been turned off but disappears when I turn it on and try to connect. None of my 4 Bluetooth audio headsets will work with the Samsung Chromebook. The lack of audio Bluetooth support is close to being a deal breaker. I recently purchased an analog to Bluetooth adapter and I suppose I can use it as a work around but that is certainly far from ideal. A second disappointment is lack of support for Netflix. I understand a fix is in the works but if not forthcoming within the 30 day returned period, I will return the Chromebook and continue my search for the perfect Windows 8 hybrid tablet / laptop.For me the jury is still out as to whether I will keep the device. I continue to bump into limitations that may be more peculiar to my usage habits than to the targeted audience for this device. Three prime examples are the lack of support for Skype, voice recognition, and Microsoft office suite. I had not used Google docs prior to purchasing the Chromebook and I am still trying to decide if I can use it is a portable replacement for my much-loved Microsoft alternatives.Bottom line: I am impressed with how functional the device is and suspect Chrome OS is here to stay and will negatively affect the bottom line of both Microsoft and Apple.The success of Android and now Chromebook OS go a long way to vindicate my Linux friends who have long predicted Linux on my desktop.Update: A. Dightam wrote to correct my claim that two finger tapping did not simulate a right click. He was right and after a bit of two finger tap, tap, tapping it works like a charm.I used my analog to Bluetooth adapter to connect to my favorite Bluetooth headset and it worked as expected. I have my fingers crossed native support for Bluetooth audio is in the works.I have tested two USB devices. My USB Xbox Vision webcam works with the camera app. Frame rate is disappointing but happy to see I have at least one alternative to the built-in camera. In anticipation of Netflix support, I connected my wireless Lenovo Multimedia Remote Keyboard and it worked flawlessly. Unlike Apple and Windows device installs, I saw no driver install message and both devices were usable within seconds of plugging into the USB socket. Sweet!Update #2:Have used HDMI out to stream Amazon movies to big screen TV and works like a charm. Still missing Netflix and Audio Blue Tooth support which could trigger my return of the unit if not forthcoming. I use a BT transmitter to pair with BT headsets but that is becoming tiresome. I am getting used to Google Docs and, given my limited laptop demands re. word processing and spreadsheet data entry, Google docs is all that is needed when using the Chromebook. The matte screen continues to impress me. Would be hard to take it back but I really depend on Bluetooth audio. I have another 10 days to decide if I am willing to wait and trust Google / Samsung to make it happen.Expiration Date Update:I happily allowed the window for returning my Chromebook expire. After trying three different Atom based Windows 8 hybrid tablet / laptop machines I settled on an Asus RT and docking keyboard. This geek never expected to purchase and use, much less like, a Windows RT device but stranger things have happened to me. Although I love the Win RT machine, I am almost equally fond of the Chromebook.The size, weight, good battery life,lovely screen, great keyboard and NO FUSS operating system made it a keeper. I am even growing fond of Google docs. The Asus Windows RT makes for a sweet tablet and I feel as secure using it as I do the Chromebook but it is not the laptop replacement I sought. As long as my portable demands remain as limited as they are now, the Chromebook makes for an excellent laptop experience.I miss Netflix, Skype, audio Bluetooth and if the price had not been so low and the Asus RT so good at filling in for these missing bits, I would have returned the Chromebook. At $200 - $250 it makes sense ... anything above that would take it a non starter for me.I changed the rating from 2 to 3 stars. Missing too many bits to warrant 4.UPDATE!!!As of March 11, 2013 Netflix is supported! BRAVO! Now for audio Bluetooth and Skype! Sweet!

I leave my left palm resting to the left of the track pad and when I do, "clicking" the trackpad by pressing down doesn't work. There is a software feature which allows you to tap the mouse for clicks, but the issue I'm talking about is the physical click by depressing the track pad. The times this is most noticeable are the following:- When resting the laptop on a soft surface, such as your lap- When the laptop is on a hard surface, but the front of the laptop hangs over the edge a bit.- This is kind of hard to explain, but sometimes when I'm walking around with my laptop, I hold it with my left hand with my four fingers on the bottom of the left side, and my thumb on the top, squeezing on the laptop with a firm grip. This allows me to use the trackpad when I'm standing, walking around... When holding the laptop like this, the trackpad click also fails. This is probably not a practice done my most people though :)* If the chromebook is on a hard surface (table) without hanging over the edge, this issue is not seen.What's more interesting is that this only happens if your hand is pressed down on the left side of the track pad. If you use your left hand to control the track pad, (with a heavy right hand), you won't notice this issue.I think having a macbook with it's aluminum unibody has given me bad habits because the construction is so solid, but when we're talking about a $1,500 price difference between the macbook and chromebook, I think it's understandable. The chromebook is a $250 laptop and you can't expect the construction to be on par with macbook. This is just a small annoyance and when it happens, I just have to remember to lift my left hand to allow the the track pad to work properly.Aside from that, I love the chromebook and find myself using it more than my macbook now because it's so light and convenient -- not to mention, you feel more comfortable casually carrying it around since you are less concerned with damaging an electronic device that is so cheap :).Sorry, one more thing -- There is no right-click with the chromebook -- you use a two finger click for a right-click functionality (one finger for left click). I like this, but when you are using multiple laptops, it's easy to forget.**** Update ****I have a terrible time streaming youtube vidoes which is why I'm assuming netflix is STILL not supported. Youtube definitely has its own issues, but I have streamed the same video side-by-side with my chromebook and macbook, and have no issues with the macbook. Furthermore, my download speed is 45mbps and upload is 5mbps, so this is not a bandwidth issue.You can pause the video and allow it to buffer (youtube only buffers so much so it may be necessary to pause several times while watching a video), but should that really be necessary? Chromebook has capable hardware, so this must be a software issue. They have fixed another major annoyance I had to deal with for a few weeks (chromebook wouldn't "wake up" when opening the lid and a hard reboot was necessary). I hold out hope this will also be addressed, but I would probably give this review 3 1/2 stars at this point and find myself having to switch back to my macbook more and more.If you like to stream a lot of video, I would NOT recommend this laptop at this point :)

I see no difference even with 2 strength bars shown for 3G.Since I am using my laptop as Guest, apparently I can't switch from wi-fi to 3G while logged in as such: When I go to the Settings page and try to enable "Mobile data" (under which there is Verizon wireless) I get a message something like "Only the owner can change that." However, the following works:1. On the Settings page disable wi-fi. It will say "not connected".2. Reboot the laptop.3. A page will appear asking you to select either a wireless network or a mobile data.4. Select "mobile data" and click on "Enable mobile data".5. Assuming you have already set up your 3G prepaid 2 year service which came with this 3G laptop, "Verizon wireless" will appear and laptop will connect to 3G.Perhaps the above steps will also work when the 3G service has not been yet enabled: it would make sense if it did by allowing one to set it up then.So, far I am enjoying this new way of working on a laptop.PS1 The above method also works when switching back from 3G to wi-fi. I hope that switching can be done while logged in as the "Owner" without rebooting (needed apparently when logged in as "Guest").PS2 I have discovered that when Chrome is connected to the Internet via 3G and I disable "Mobile data" on the Settings page, it automatically reconnects to my last-used wi-fi network! Neat!

computer|With an extremely appealing price tag ($249), I bought a google Chromebook under the impression of an economical, futuristic laptop, without even reading a single review or doing any research. Hindsight is 20/20. What I got was none short a surprise. The Chromebook has apparently been around since June 2011, and this is just the newest addition.The Chromebook is unlike the conventional laptop in many fashions. The biggest difference is that without a wi-fi connection, the new Chromebook is almost literally a paperweight. Unlike most other laptops on the market today, the Chromebook doesn&#8217;t run Windows 8 or some kind of Mac OS, rather it runs &#8220;Chrome OS&#8221;, which in my perspective looks like the android OS put onto a laptop, with none of a tablets capabilities. This new, linux driven operating system is not compatible with most common programs that PC and Mac users alike don such as Microsoft Office, Photoshop, Flash, and the like. Instead, all the applications that the Chromebook run are in-browser inside of Google Chrome. Everything you do on this laptop os through the Google Chrome browser.When I learned that my new Chromebook was basically useless without an internet connection I didn&#8217;t want to fret. I figured I would just buy some sort of 4G plan so I could utilize my Chromebook no matter where I am. Then brief research revealed that this is the first Chromebook that doesn&#8217;t have 4G plans available to it and is completely dependant on having a nearby wi-fi connection. Google itself has described this computer as &#8220;an extra computer for around the house.&#8221; and I would have to agree.If you&#8217;re considering the new Chromebook to replace your desktop PC or current laptop, think again. computer|Why did I buy a Chromebook when I already have two MacBook Air (an 11.6 and a 13 inch, both with i5 processors), an iPad, a Kindle Fire, a Samsung Galaxy Tab and a Windows XP laptop? Well, first, I'm a technology hog. I have a perverse need to try everything at least once. Second, my wife spilled wine on my 11.6 MacBook Air, which now has a semi-functional keyboard, so I wanted to have a really inexpensive sacrificial laptop to protect me from future accidents. (If your spouse needs to spill wine on your laptop, I would suggest very dry wine, with a really low sugar content.)So, what's good about the Samsung Chromebook, aside from the really low price? The keyboard is quite good. I like it as much as that of the MacBook Air, well, at least before it had white wine dumped all over it. The next desirable attribute would be simplicity. Open the cover, hit the on button, connect to Wifi, sign in with your Google account credentials and you are off to the races. There's no need to buy software, keep your antiviral software up to date or backup your data. Your data is stored in Google's cloud, where Google keeps it backed up, and this also makes your data available to you via other household computers, tablets, smart phones, and even computers you do not own like the one in the waiting room at your car dealership. The trackpad works quite well, although up and down scrolling is opposite to that on the Mac, which is rather confusing.As others have observed, the display is adequate.What's not to like? As a practical matter, there is no way to connect this computer to a printer. There are work-arounds, but I don't consider them practical. Even my iPhone and iPad provide a practical way to print: the Lantronix XPrintServer. Need to visit a website that runs Java scripts? Not gonna happen. This computer does not run Java. Before purchasing the Chromebook I understood that software choices would be quite limited. But I assumed that Google Docs would allow me to view and make minor edits to Word files I had already created on a "real" computer. What surprised me is that Google Docs cannot display certain embedded objects (such as chemical structures) in my Word files. So, while this computer is extremely compact and light, making it attractive for travel, it may not be powerful enough for business, depending upon your line of work.So, what is the Chromebook good for? I think it is ideally suited for someone who wants to do email and some web browsing, has very little understanding of or patience for the care and feeding of computers, and does not need to print. In short, its great for your 87 year old mother or your 75 year old mother-in-law. But for the rest of us, get a real computer.

computer|I just received my Chromebook and think it's a fabulous concept and design. It works well except for one major problem which may force me to return it. It will not go into sleep mode. The power button is illuminated, but no action (tapping the touch pad, keys, even the power button) will wake it up. The same thing happens when I close the lid, which the instructions state is supposed to put it to sleep. To restart it, I have to hold down the power button for about 15 seconds to do a force-shutdown, and then push the power button again to restart the system. Also, when the computer is stuck in the not-sleep hanging suspended mode, it is draining the battery. (When in an actual sleep mode, the computer is not draining its battery.) So not only is this inconvenient and troubling, but all of the extra force-shutdowns and restarts are hard on the system and surely shortening the lifespan of the computer and its battery.I went on the Google user forum and discovered that perhaps a dozen users registered the same problem. One use had a workaround, but it's inconvenient (you can't let the computer idle into sleep; you have to sign out and shutdown each time you stop using the machine for awhile). Then I emailed a Chrome Google Ninja. I'm afraid I'll have to return this otherwise nice computer, and while I'd like to get one that works properly, I don't know how many of the ones in stock have this defect. I hope the Google folks read this, since they are generally brilliant and surely can fix this.

computer|Love it. Easy start; does what we were expecting. Holds a charge long enough to do what we need. Recommend
computer|I had never even considered a windows netbook because of their general sluggish performance, and chromebooks always seemed like the solution... except for the 400-500 price. When this new version came out at only 249 I knew I had to get it. I was thrilled when the laptop arrived. It's the thinnest and lightest laptop I've ever used, and very zippy on the inside.First I'll start with the hardware. The build quality is so-so. It looks pretty similar to the Macbook Air, but don't be confused, it is PLASTIC. It flexes pretty easily, which at first I was very concerned for, but after about a month of use it hasn't been an issue. Well, there is one problem. The touchpad is slightly sunken in one corner, but that hasn't bothered me too much.The keyboard is perfect, and I mean perfect. I can tell my WPM has increased, which is saying a lot because I'm the fastest typist I know. I actually didn't know it doesn't have a caps lock key, that was a fun surprise when it came. Instead there is a search key, which lets you look through your Apps as well as straight-up google. I haven't missed the caps lock key at all, and if you think you'd need to have access to it easily, there is a keyboard shortcut for it (I think it's shift-search or something like that). Another thing that I found weird is that the power key is just another key, like not a separate button. There is a small light in the key though, so I have only accidentally hit it once haha.As far as the screen goes, this was my first experience with a matte screen. It has the same resolution as my previous laptop (1280x726 I THINK, something like that anyway) but it's a lot smaller (that one was 15.6 I think?), so it's pretty sharp. It's not a glossy screen, so it does better at reflecting light. Its viewing angles leave a lot to be desired, but because of it's small size it's not hard to find a good angle. I've used this laptop to watch a lot of movies and it performs pretty well. The built in media player is pretty limited but good enough. It's extremely bright, though, and has a feature that automatically adjusts the brightness depending on your surroundings.The trackpad, I'll be honest, I was very nervous about. I've used macbook airs & pros for the last few years but also a desktop running Windows 7. Bu man was I surprised at how natural it felt. Most of the mutli-touch gestures are there, such as two-click right click, three-click middle click, two finger scrolling which, in my opinion, blows mac's out of the water. Weirdly enough, a few functions have disappeared. When I got my laptop it included left & right two-touch gestures for 'back' and 'forward' functions in the browser, but those disappeared with an update (though there are dedicated &#60;- and -&#62; keys for this purpose). Pinch-to-zoom is reportedly in the works but not here yet. I'll also note that it does support tap to click, so you don't have to physically push down the button, just tap it. Overall I was very happy with the trackpad's performance.USB 2.0 AND 3.0 have proven very useful, as well as the SD slot (though as I mentioned it does stick out a bit, but it's no problem for me). No VGA but there is HDMI, which face it, is all you really need these days. I haven't tried streaming it through my Bluray player, but I still have my desktop for that.One more thing, there is no disk drive.Now on to Chrome OS, or as it used to be called, Chromium. I found the media format limitations pretty disappointing. I couldn't play a lot of my movies on it, and there is currently no support for Netflix. Honestly that's pretty lame. It has been confirmed to be in the works but I'm not expecting anything to come out of it soon. Once Netflix support does arrive though, the laptop's versatility will be tons better.There is a basic file manager, arranged in files just like Windows, as well as a task manager that was very natural to use. You can pin items to your taskbar, just like windows 7, which I was very happy with. Most of what you do will be in the chrome browser, which syncs all the info across all your devices. But there are also 'apps' you can use. Honestly, most of these are just links to regular websites, which are certainly useful, especially when your bookmark bar is full. Some of them are different though, like a few games. By far my favourite and most-used app is the New York Times, which provides a perfect online experience that puts their regular website to shame.On a side note, I have had a few problems with the laptop displaying some websites' mobile version. Accounts for basically the whole star taken off.Anyway, this chromebook is the perfect solution for the on-the-go problem that bigger, heavier laptops present. Make no mistake, it is not a primary computer, mostly because of software & media format limitations, but it has been the best secondary computing machine I have come across, and for the 249 price you can't go wrong. It doesn't have the app selection of the cheaper, 199 Nexus 7, but the full-size keyboard and Chrome OS make it feel more like a laptop than a tablet in a good way. If you do most of your work in Google Drive like me, this laptop will fulfill all your needs in the classroom and conveniently sinks in the cloud (it comes with 100GB of Drive storage for 2 years) so you can pick up where you left off on your windows machine. The battery lasts all day (I consistently have it last 7 hours using google docs, even better than the 6.5 hours it says) and I don't even notice the weight when I carry it. At 249 it's a bargain that you can't pass up, whether it's for you secondary computer or your kid's first.
