computer|The latest Chromebook from Samsung based on ARM processor is a great bargain at $250. Very solid keyboard, light, long lasting battery, nice looking when closed.I wish the display would be better quality. I would gladly pay extra $50 for a higher res 12'' IPS display instead what comes in the package. Display is matte but not very bright and not very contrasty, so the the matte quality goes to waste in bright sun anyway. It does not reflect your surroundings but since it is not an IPS display you end up constantly adjusting the screen to face you perfectly. Otherwise contrast is lost very quickly. How quickly, you ask? Well, if I am sitting on a sofa with Chromebook on my lap, even slight change of my head position is enough for contrast going way down. It usually results in whole screen getting darker, the dark areas all becoming black blobs and colors desaturating. Also, since Samsung put an 11.6'' display and full size keyboard, there is a lot of wasted space around the display. It frankly looks cheap. That's why this laptop won't turn anyone's head when opened. The resolution of 1366x768 results in text not overly sharp, especially for aged eyes. 1600x900 would be much better.The touchpad is a bit cramped. I understand that it is a limitation of the laptop size, but it does result in need to constantly adjust your fingers position so you won't bump against touchpad border. I am also not a big fan of the location of the ports. All of them, except SD card slot are on the back of Chromebook. This only works when Chromebook is set on the flat surface like table. Put it on you lap and you will risk breaking the ports since power and USB plugs will be vulnerable to any movement or adjusting your position.Speaking of the SD card slot, the design of it bewilders me. When you insert your card in the port it ends up sticking half-way out of the port, like in USB card readers. This is first time I am seeing this implementation in laptop form. Again, extremely vulnerable and easy to break your card and possibly damage the port if you bump the side against any surface, even soft. This also pretty much precludes you from putting an SD card in and leaving it permanently in the Chromebook as a much needed extra storage.Otherwise, Wi-Fi antenna is good. Google claims that it is dual-band dual-antenna design but I found that it is not very speedy. My Kindle Fire HD beats Chromebook handily in both throughput and range. Speakers are very weak. The worst speakers from all the laptops that I used. It is on the same range as typical tablet speakers. Again, Kindle Fire HD showed that one does not need to have big shell to produce big sound. Overall I would rate hardware at two stars but since the price is so affordable, I would bump one star up.Now as for software. First thing that strikes you is an instant on. The moment I pull up the display it is on and ready to work. Wi-Fi takes about 5 seconds to reestablish connection but by the time you unlock your Chromebook and click any link on the browser it is already on. Chromebook comes with the best PC browser in Google Chrome. Almost all PC extensions work without glitch. My Chrome is equipped with AdBlock, LastPass, ProxySwitch, SpeedDial, Camelizer, XMarks BookMark Sync and others and all of them work on Chromebook the same way as on PC. Some specialized extensions like Clickability Portal do not work. The combination of the Samsung Exynos 5 Dual core CPU, Chrome browser and 2GB of RAM results in great performance. Few dynamic HTML heavy sites lag a little but overall I can not complain. Multi-tabbing works perfectly too. I often have dozen+ sites open at once and usually do not experience any performance degradation.Now, why I call Chrome OS as half-baked. Because it is. First of all, IMO Chrome is a dead-end as OS. Android can do all the same things better and is so much more. Google also does not put much effort in maintaining and updating an OS. Example? Well, how about touchpad gestures. Chrome OS comes with total of 5 gestures! That's right. There is no back or forward gesture, there is no zoom in or zoom out gesture. All you have is move cursor, click, right click, scroll and drag-and-drop. That is it, folks. I have Windows 8 laptop and it takes me an hour just to familiarize myself with all possible gestures, including three finger and four finger gestures. Android and iOS both come with multi-gesture friendly displays. Chromebook relies heavily on keyboard shortcuts, of which there is almost a hundred possible combinations with Ctrl, Alt or Shift keys. Again, great keyboard, so if you are working on your Chromebook at the desk there are no complains. But if you browse Internet or playing some lightweight games on the sofa, you would try to minimize keyboard interaction and rely more on touchpad and the limited functionality of what it can do in Chrome OS is evident compared to all other modern OS. I can connect mouse and enable one of the Chrome mouse gestures extensions but again, it only works on the desk. You just don't use mouse on your lap or anywhere else.Then comes multimedia playback or lack of. YouTube works just fine. No complaints there. Amazon videos can only be watched in standard resolution. It looks ugly. Netflix does not work. Now, many will say that both Google and Netflix are working on the fix and it should be available shortly. Call me realist. I've seen many times before how the 'shortly' projections drag for months and months and at the end of the day Netflix does not have much incentive to be in any hurry because of the negligible market share that Samsung ARM-based Chromebook have. Local video playback is also lousy. Chromebook comes with only a handful of codec and formats supported and outside or re-encoding each and every video in Chromebook friendly format, you will find a very sporadic support. Many of my videos do not play at all. Sometimes if I change file extension to one of Chromebook supported ones the video would work but not the sound. In other words it's unreliable at best and frustrating to no means at worst. Coupled with mediocre display and worse speakers, if you are planning to use it for any entertainment purposes - don't.Google Docs are adequate. I would rate it the lowest from the list of MS Office, Libre and Open Office alternatives. Google Docs are sufficient for some undemanding word or presentation prep work but lacks pretty much any advanced features. Since it is Cloud-based Office suite (you can work with Google Docs offline too), there is an instant save as you type, so I can work on any document, close the display, go to cafe across the street, reopen it and continue working without any loss of data.Where Chromebook shines is in Google Services integration. It comes with 100GB of Cloud storage for two years free of charge, courtesy of Chromebook promotion. The promotion is only valid for the one user and one Chromebook. In other words, if you plan to have to users working on Chromebook, only one can claim the extra space. If you buy couple of Chromebooks and try to claim space on both of them, single user can only claim the first promotion but not any subsequent. If you sell your Chromebook or gift it after claiming the space, it can not be reclaimed by any other user. So be aware of this. Chromebook comes with Gmail set up and ready to use. There is even offline functionality, so you can look at older Emails and reply without necessary connecting to the Internet. next time you reconnect, Chromebook will automatically sync all the Emails.Chrome App Store is very limited compared to Android marketplace or iOS App Store. I would say it's on the level with B&N Nook store. Which is, on other words, nothing to write about. Most of the apps are nothing more then URL links to the vendor web site. Netflix, Pandora, even Youtube do not have any specialized interface. So I do not think of these as Apps, because I much rather have them in my Bookmarks then exposed from the bottom menu. None of the apps go automatically into full screen mode. This is another are where Chrome OS lacks severely compared to all other modern OS. Even Microsoft has recognized with Windows 8 that full screen mode is very beneficial when you want to focus on the primary application and give it as much screen real estate as possible. Google Chrome OS lives in the browser with all of the extra bars both on top and bottom that eat into already very limited vertical space. To switch to full screen there is an obscure Shift-Maximize keyboard shortcut. Good luck executing it when on a sofa with Chromebook on your lap.Overall I really can not recommend this laptop. The price is right and the keyboard is excellent (back lighting would help it even more) but the rest of the package just is not there. If you want something very portable and ready to work with limited Google Docs suite, it's fine. For everything else there are better alternatives. General Web Browsing with occasional Email - tablets are better because of touchscreen and better fitted apps. Entertainment - tablets are in it's own class. Productivity - Windows-based laptops are way more flexible. Gaming - depending on casual or hardcore, either tablets or PC are better in all respects.

computer|Think about it for a moment, does a person need more than a browser (and tools for software development if that is your job)? What more does a person need in life than browsing and software development? My browsing is mainly to get ideas or sample code or solve specific problems by looking up error messages or get library call references. Is email as important as that? Probably mostly a needless distraction but it can be done adequately in a browser.Do we really need budgeting software? Overkill. Keep some numbers in a text file or online or (like me) don't bother. Word processing? I use probably 1/2 dozen menu (sorry ribbon) choices in Word and the rest just get in the way. Spreadsheets? Do it online or if you are doing serious data processing, write some code. Likewise for image processing, do it at an online site or write your own which is very easy with libraries available for most programming languages.The first thing we need to do with this machine is switch to developer mode (google for that). Second we need to run programs. First realize that the way this system is designed, it will run whatever programs are installed and no more. So first remount the home filesystem to execute programs in it:ionsudo mount -o exec,remount /homeWe can easily install software by remounting other filesystems as read/write and using normal installers. But I don't want to do that because I am trying to keep as close as possible to one design philosophy of the machine which is don't muck around in / or /usr or similar locations.Having remounted /home you can now run any software you want. But one catch is that the libraries for most packages would normally be in /lib. So be prepared to set your LD_LIBRARY_PATH in your .bashrc Next we need to find software that will run on this OS and processor. Specifically we need "armhf" I like to use the debian distribution and find the packages and the dependencies myself. To do that I locate the package I want in [...] by clicking through the hierarchy (first I switch to the testing distribution - wheezy). The package is in a .deb format file so I do this on a mac. Using ruby as an example, I find that it needs libc6, so I click to this page:Download Page for libc6_2.13-38_armhf.deb on ARM Hard Float machinesand download the file. Next extract the contents:ar x libc6_2.13-38_armhf.debgzcat data.tar.gz | tar xf -This creates a usr directory in my home directory. I do that for about 8 or 10 more dependencies plus the program itself (in this case ruby). Ruby is probably about average complexity in terms of library usage. This is more tedious than apt-get or similar programs, but AFAIK those do not work without writing into the system directories.Once all the files have been extracted for ruby and emacs (all I want), we set our LD_LIBRARY_PATH in .bashrc. Note that I put ruby and emacs in separate directories in my home directory, but that is not necessary.export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="/home/chronos/user/ruby/usr/lib"export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}:/home/chronos/user/ruby/usr/lib/arm-linux-gnueabihf/gconv/"export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}:/home/chronos/user/emacs/lib/arm-linux-gnueabihf"export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}:/home/chronos/user/emacs/usr/lib/arm-linux-gnueabihf"Tell Ruby where its libraries are tell emacs where the lisp is:export RUBYLIB="/home/chronos/user/ruby/usr/lib/ruby/1.9.1"export EMACSLOADPATH="~/emacs/usr/share/emacs/23.4/lisp/emacs-lisp/"Finally make aliases to run ruby and emacs (or make symlinks and modify PATH instead):alias ruby='~/ruby/usr/bin/ruby1.9.1'alias emacs='~/emacs/usr/bin/emacs23-nox'Now comes an important caveat with this computer/OS. The browser eats all the important control keys, so we can't edit using emacs without downloading the terminal shell. So go to the Chrome store and get some software:[...]I downloaded and installed "crosh window" and "secure shell". What I ended up with is a separate window that I run chrome's shell in, which does not eat control or other meta keys but sends all key strokes to the application inside the window.And that's it, you now have a development station with good screen resolution and GIANT control and alt keys in the lower left corner. There simply is not a better key layout than that. The keys are chiclet and a little clacky. The case is plastic, but the form factor is great - very thin and light. Battery life is great although sleep eats battery more than than my mac. The computer is silent, the USB slots are on the back, the sd card sticks out the side. I would rather have it all sticking out the back because then I can put the computer in a small case and let the cards and sticks stick out the top.The only downside that I have run into is a slight pause every now and then. It seems that stops everything, shell prompts, keystrokes into the shell, etc. Also scrolling complex pages will show a crosshatch screen while the drawing tries to catch up (no pause however). The machine could be underpowered for some people's tastes but not for mine. I lose no productivity with a little noticeable lag every now and then (maybe a couple times a day).Installing the extra software like above takes effort, but I believe it is worth it. For one thing I can tar up my home directory and reinstall it after the OS is upgraded. Using this machine for software development purposes (emacs and ruby in my case) is a breeze. It is highly productive and cost effective.

After a few moments it would find my iPhone and, after entering the password the first time, reconnect automatically after that. I found that it almost always lost the connection after "sleeping." computer|They say the best camera you own is the one you carry. If this were true for computers as well, this would be a winner.(+) Fits in my messenger bag designed to hold only an iPad.(+) Ridiculously light for something with ~6 hours of battery life.(+) Cheaper than most tablets and ultrabooks.(+) Quiet (except for the keyboard)(+) Extremely fast bootup and shutdown times.The problem is that outside of size and battery life, you have to make compromises in every single arena.(-) Poor build quality, cheap plastic feeling case that actually flexes if you squeeze it with your thumbs.(-) Cheap chiclet keyboard that actually squeaks -- my backspace key does every time it is depressed.(-) Jerky single-button touch pad.(-) The worst LCD screen I've ever used, with an extremely limited vertical viewing angle -- off 15 degrees and it's a mess.(-) Speakers so weak that turning on the kitchen faucet drowns them out, even on max volume.(-) No Evernote, no Skype, no Microsoft Office, no real work possible.(-) A long, thin, unprotected power plug only a few millimeters wide that can easily be damaged.I'm trying to wrap my head around the ideal demographic for this device and can only come up with:- Computer illiterate people who need to surf the Internet or check their email a few times a month.- Tweens and other children who need a cheap, restricted Internet device.- Professionals who need Google Docs thin clients.- Students and other people who spend a lot of time writing documents while on the go.The only thing this Chromebook has over an equivalently priced Android tablet is a mediocre keyboard. The only thing this Chromebook has over a somewhat equivalent Windows ultrabook is price. There is such a shortage of good Chrome apps that it makes the Windows 8 app store look like a treasure trove. If you really need a keyboard, you would do better purchasing something like an ASUS Transformer Pad, which costs ~$100 more, but has twice the battery life and is better in every single aspect except bootup and shutdown times.What will make the Chromebook worthwhile? If it can get Skype, Evernote, and other productivity apps onboard so the Chromebook can be used for something other than just web browsing. Otherwise there's no reason to buy this over, say, any dual core $200 Android tablet. The only reason I'm keeping this is that I do spend time typing on the go. I will more than likely give this up when the Microsoft Surface Pro is released. Yes, it costs a lot more, but it's also a lot more than just a web browser with a keyboard.Make no mistake: the Chromebook seems like a steal if you compare it to an ultrabook, but this is no ultrabook by any means. It is only an ultrabook in form, not function.

computer|If you think this is a computer, you have been lied to and are mistaken. The Chromebook is a web browser and glorified typewriter. It can do nothing else. What you can do on the Chrome browser on a real computer is all you are limited to on the Chromebook. Anything else is a fantasy. The worst part, the ARM dual core A15 and Mali GPU is very overrated. The CPU and "GPU" is so underpowered, that the functions the Chromebook can perform lag, video stutters, flash games take minutes to load and when they finally do they stutter and lag as well. The desktop area is just a picture, you can't make shortcuts to anything, but it makes sense since there is nothing to link to. Don't be fooled by all the "satisfied" customers who "knew what they were getting into when they ordered their Chromebook." Those people probably never owned a real computer or even a tablet and this is a step up from the calculator and typewriter they were using before. If you have $300 to spend, buy a tablet or a decent netbook. Or, spend a few buck more and get a real laptop. Whatever you do, do not buy this steaming pile of junk.

computer|I bought a Chromebook to replace my old PC laptop that I used at home. I have a PC laptop for work but don't like to use it for my personal stuff like downloading music, organizing pictures, etc. I realize that Chromebook is meant to be a netbook, or webbook, or whatever the new generation of cloud based devices is called. However, I did my research on the Chromebook beforehand and it seemed that I'd be able to do a lot of things that I could do on a laptop. I was willing to try out something new at this price point.The price was certainly right at $250 from Best Buy, and the thing boots up beautifully right out of the box. It's a nice little compact computer with a decent screen and keyboard. Too bad it doesn't do anything that a machine of its size should do.Before you buy one of these, realize that you cannot sync an iPod to it, you cannot download MS Office to it, and you cannot even upload music into Google Play from it. The first two are somewhat understandable, but if I buy this thing wanting to switch to Google's ecosystem, shouldn't I be able to at least listen to music that I ported from a memory stick? It's absolutely ridiculous that I have to keep an old Windows laptop so that I can manage my music on Google Play and then listen to it with the Chromebook. I bought the Chromebook so that I could replace the old Windows laptop. If Google wants people to switch from traditional local storage based computing, it should design Chromebook so that you don't have to rely on an old PC to use Google's services.I haven't even mentioned yet how slow it was to upload files from a memory stick to Google Drive on the Chromebook. I suspect the problem is with Google Drive and not the Chromebook, but you have to use Drive to access your files with the Chromebook, so it doesn't make any difference where the problem is. I had 20 gigs of files to upload -- it took an entire weekend. The problem was not with my Internet connection, as I speed tested at over 4 Mbps upload.The Chromebook is still a consumption machine, maybe a little more powerful than a tablet, but there's no way I'm using it to do anything substantial like draft a letter or make a presentation. Google's web-based office services are just not anywhere close to MS Office, and won't be for some time. Google Drive isn't ready for prime time either. I have an Android phone and tablet and love them, but the Chromebook is little more than a tablet with a keyboard.
